title: Port Hills firefighters: 'They are the example for your kids to aspire to'
text:
Port Hills firefighters: 'They are the example for your kids to aspire to' CHARLIE MITCHELL Last updated 18:45, February 17 2017 JOHN KIRK-ANDERSON/FAIRFAX NZ 
Paul Dorrance's house on Worsleys Spur was saved due to the heroic efforts of firefighters. 
It wasn't luck that saved Paul Dorrance's house from the flames – it was nothing short of heroism. 
The Port Hills fire stormed towards his Worsley Spur property on Thursday morning, painting the hills black with ash. 
A photo of the aftermath – his seemingly unblemished house shrouded in smoke, circled by charred trees – has become symbolic of the efforts by firefighters to protect property. IAIN MCGREGOR/FAIRFAX NZ 
A helicopter protecting the house. 
Dorrance was herding his cows away from the approaching fire, fearing the worst, when the cavalry arrived. 
"Like everyone, I was peering at it from a distance," he said. 
"There would have been about eight loaders and diggers charging up the hill, right next to the fire, doing fire breaks." 
They powered "literally through the fire," exposing themselves to significant danger, he said, while helicopter pilots flew above the flames with monsoon buckets. 
The ordeal brought back memories of the earthquakes, when that same house had been destroyed. 
After five years of rebuilding, it looked to be destroyed once again – and it would have been if the firefighters hadn't risked their lives. 
"I suspect many of them were also on hand in those terrible days post earthquake," Dorrance said. Ad Feedback 
"These guys never seek the limelight and deserve considerable recognition. There absolutely needs to be something there for those pilots and the member of their team that went down." 
Until he could get to his house, he couldn't be sure it was entirely undamaged, but it looked to be in "great nick." 
Some of his neighbours had lost their homes. Others like him still had theirs – not because of luck, but because of bravery. 
"There was a fireman who posted a Snapchat of himself in front of the house, and what I was told was, all those people were just so proud they had saved a house. I just think that's amazing. 
"My home will always be an open and welcoming place to anyone who participated in its survival and that of the Spur. I mean that genuinely. 
"They are the example for your kids to aspire to."
